act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Today, I was lying on a pallet in the canteen, which also serves as our library, drinking 100 grams to myself and reading Anna Karenina when Oleg stopped by. Can I have a sip of that, he asked. Reluctantly, I passed him a shot glass.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He drank it down pretentiously. "Ah," he said, smacking his lips, "reading Tolstoy, I see. So how are you getting on with Anishka Karenina?"

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "It's a masterpiece," I said. "Each page is a revelation. The metaphysical aspects alone--"

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "Isn't Count Vronsky such a cad?" he interrupted. "Will he ever settle down? Interesting how that turns out."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "I'm sure it is," I said, "but, please, don't tell me anymore." "Of course," he said. "How can I deny you the pleasure of a first reading of Anna Karenina? I'll just make myself a little lunch.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He went over to the microwave and warmed himself a plate of kasha with whale sausage. Then he sat down to his smelly little feast. And then as I continued reading, he began softly humming to himself. "Chug-a chug-a chug-a chug-a chug-a chug-a choo choo!" And then he laughed.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "What is the meaning of this," I asked. "Oh, nothing," he said. "Just, living in Antarctica-- do you know what I miss the most? Trains. In particular, a train station in Moscow.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Once, I was quite drunk after a literary soiree, and my ex-girlfriend almost slipped and fell onto the tracks. Strangely enough, her name was Anna also-- but not Anna Karenina, Anna Kashtanova. Sounds pretty close, though."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "Why are you telling me this?" I said.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "Oh, just babbling on," he said. "Well, never mind me. Off to do some science."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "You mean welding!" I shouted after him, but he had already waddled out of the library. I will make one unkind observation-- many intellectuals I have known walk like penguins. I don't know why that is so, but it is so.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: The whole night, I tossed in my bunk. I kept hearing Oleg's voice in my head-- my girlfriend almost slipped and fell. Train station. Her name was Anna.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: I got up and paced the corridors. They were devoid of life, devoid of hope. I stole into the canteen and had just one little sip, maybe 120 grams. Later that night, in my dreams, Putin asked me onto his horse.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Dear Diary, well, the penguins are still frozen. This morning, I tried them with my penguin knife, stabbing them over and over. Maybe tomorrow I can start making my steaks, and then all the boys in the hunt team will love me.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: After a long, hard day of serious scientific research, I retired to the canteen, blissfully returning to my Anna Karenina, and, for good measure, tippling 200 grams. I was deep into the book when Oleg rattled in, carrying something heavy and metallic looking in his arms.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "Brother," he shouted, "look what I've welded for you." And he set down the object in his hands. It looked like the model of a 19th century train station.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He had built it down to the little vendors hawking [NON-ENGLISH]. And in the middle of it all stood a miniature doll he had made out to look like an American cheerleader. She had the letters "AK" written on her chest.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Oleg saying, "chug-a chug-a, chug-a, chug-a, chug-a, chug-a, chug-a, chug-a, choo, choo!" As he ran his miniature train out of the station and then the AK doll stepped off the platform and between the carriages. "Oi, oi, it hurts," Oleg shouted in a feminine voice. "I'm dying."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: I put my book down. "Are you saying Anna Karenina commits suicide," I whispered. "Oh, no," he said. "It's Anna Kashtanova, my ex-girlfriend. I'm merely recreating her tragic end. You are so sensitive, Sergey. Well, I must be off now. Science can't wait."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "Welding," I muttered after him. I tried to return to the book, but my mind was raging with thought. I had to know if it was true.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Oh, Anna, beloved Anna. If you die in such a grisly manner, what hope is there for any of us? I drank another 250 grams just to make it an even 450. I sat there calmly, doing the breathing exercises that Westerners like to do after they visit India.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: But then I couldn't help it. I logged on to one of our base's allowed web sites, VladimirPutinDiscussesFineLiterature.gov. An image of my sober, beautifully coiffed president sitting on a comfortable chair with a blanket over his legs appeared. Our president is, of course, as brilliant at literature as he is at economics and evading sanctions.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He lifted one finger, looked into the camera and said, hello, fellow reading enthusiast. Before we begin our discussion, let me issue one spoiler alert. Anna commits suicide by jumping under a train.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: I took my penguin knife, and I stabbed at Oleg's train station model. I stabbed and stabbed at it, but it might as well have been made of iron. And then I stabbed at his Anna Karenina, or Anna Kashtanova doll. I stabbed at her while thick vodka tears ran down my cheeks.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Dear Diary, today I turn over a new leaf. Anna Karenina is finished for me, but I have found an old Soviet edition of an American novel, The Complaint of Tovarich Partnoy by the writer Philip Roth. And then Oleg walked in.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: "Hey, brother," he said. "Could you spare 50 grams for my parched throat?" I merely grunted and pointed at the carafe of vodka. "Ah, I see you're a Philip Roth fan," he said, pouring himself a mug. "What a delightful look at the sexual mores of 1960s America."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: I pretended not to hear him. "So many lively scenes," he continued. "But I will not spoil them for you." Again, I pretended not to hear him.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He drank another mug of vodka. Then he went over to the refrigerator and made a show of rummaging through its contents. "There's only one slice of deer liver left," he said. "Would you mind if I have it? I so love liver."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: I shrugged my shoulders and buried myself deeper into the first pages of the book. "I must say, I love liver even more than Tovarich Portnoy loved liver." Again, I ignored him. "Liver," Oleg shouted. "It is so filled with sexy nutrients."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He hopped on the dining table, waving the red slice of deer liver at me. "Sergey," he said, "dance with me and this liver. Dance with me like a woman. Dance with me like my beloved former girlfriend, Anna Kashtanova, who died under a train in Moscow."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: And he began to dance slowly and absurdly, thrusting his hips at the liver while singing a popular old song about riding a deer over a frigid landscape.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Oleg just laughed and continued dancing while I sat there with my book, my hands shaking. But I held myself in check. I did not say a word. Finally he grew tired and hopped off the table. He gave me a wink and said, "So, now he may perhaps to begin, yes?"

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: As soon as he left, I ran to the computer and booted up VladimirPutinDiscussesFineLiterature.gov. Of course there was a segment on The Complaint of Tovarich Portnoy. Ours is a well-read president with beautiful blue eyes and the soft gaze of a benevolent father.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Putin was sitting in an easy chair beside a fireplace with a Dachschund curled at his feet, holding a copy of the Philip Roth book. "Hello, fellow literary citizens," he said brightly. "Before we begin, spoiler alert."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Dear diary, I can't. I can't anymore. But I mustn't.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: I mustn't do anything rash. I must hold it together. I try to hide under the palette, read my books without him noticing. But he hears my kasha belches, and then he pounces month after month after month.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: One month, he walked in wearing the most unusual outfit. And as I focused my gaze, I realized he was dressed as a high society woman in post-World War I London. "Oh, hello. I'm Mrs. Dalloway. I really should have married that fascinating Peter Walsh instead of boring, predictable Mr. Dalloway. I wonder how my party will go tonight."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Or dressed in prison stripes as Raskolnikov, off to Siberia to find a spiritual redemption. Or creating computer generated imagery of the white whale thrashing Captain Ahab's boat to pieces. Where? Where does he find the time to do all of these things?

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Every time he spoils an ending, it is an assault. An assault and a robbery. He has robbed me of the only pleasures this forsaken base can offer, the ability to leave my own consciousness and enter another's, the chance to fly away from this base, the snowbound version of hell, to London, to the great open sea, to the fabled town of Newark, New Jersey.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: No, I mustn't do it. I will not do it. But every night, the same dream, the same knife, the same dead Oleg. I am not Raskolnikov. I will not go to Siberia. But even if I did do something, it would not be a crime. It would be the self-defense of my very sanity.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: Dear Diary, I spent the morning in the loading bay slicing up my penguin steaks. Some of the boys from the hunt team came and cheered me on. We drank 500 grams each, and I wrestled with one of them beneath the endless sky.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: It was a happy start to the day, but still I was not satisfied. I needed more literature. I finished my vodka and, covered in penguin entrails, stumbled toward the canteen. I chose another English language book in translation, one with a sprightly title-- Shopagolik Takes Manhattan, by the British author Sophie Kinsella.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: The cover promised to tell the tale of the, quote, "irrepressible one-woman shopping phenomenon Becky Bloomwood." I opened the book, eyeing the doorway for any signs of Oleg. Shopagolik was a remarkable volume, so full of life and love and the deep, meaningful conflicts of upper middle-class men and women in the West. It was, in some ways, an instruction manual on how to live with the one you love.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: He walked in after I was about 700 grams into my carafe. "You stink of penguin," he said. "But I still love you, brother." I picked up my knife and brandished it in the air. This was the equivalent of a warning shot.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: But Oleg paid me no mind. "Ah," he said. "Shopagolik Takes Manhattan-- what a fine way to break up the interminable Antarctic day. He climbed on the table again. "Dance with me, Sergey," he said. "Dance like the Shopagolik danced in Manhattan. Now, I have always wondered about the denouement of that novel..."

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: gary shteyngart
utterance: But he never finished his sentence. I was on him. We were both off the table on the floor, reeking of cigarette butts and spilled vodka. The knife was quick and sure in my hands. And his chest soft and flabby, nothing like our president's, received my fevered blows. There was blood everywhere. "How's that for an ending," I shouted.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: Punta Arenas, Chile. Dear Diary, it has been a week since I've been airlifted here. My care is good, and the doctors and nurses are nice. One nurse, Fernanda, smiles at me in a special way as she brings me my lunch of chicken asada. I must learn Spanish.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: I do not know why Sergey stabbed me. I thought he was my friend. I was certainly his only friend. He was a drunken lout-- lazy, constantly muttering about politics and some nonsense Putin literary site.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: They found his diary after they arrested him. Vodka does not really have a smell, but every page reeked of it. Every page was a testament to his drunken haze. Talk about fiction.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: Yes, maybe I told him of a few of the endings. But it is only because I wanted to talk to him about other things. Not just about novels, but about my ailing mother in a little village near Omsk, and the girl from the Regional Planning Bureau who once sort of smiled at me. And-- look, I spoiled the endings so that we could move on to affairs of the heart and the soul.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: But I never dressed up like Mrs. Dalloway. How do you think I could afford a Mrs. Dalloway costume on a Russian welder's salary? It was merely my snow parka.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: And a computer generated recreation of Moby Dick? And dancing with a deer liver? What the hell?

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: Fine, maybe I did build a recreation of a 19th-century Moscow railroad station. I mean, who wouldn't? I wanted to bring the story to life for him.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: And I wanted him to be my friend. Because God knows, nobody else would. All the other men on the base hated the very drunken sight of him.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: And there is no penguin hunt team. Hunting penguins is illegal. Sergey disappeared into books to avoid life, to avoid me, to make a religion out of his loneliness. He didn't want to know how it would all end.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: But we all know how it ends, don't we? Ask Ahab. Ask Anna Karenina. Ask that fucking Shopagolik.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: josh gad
utterance: Down at the base, the dome of the endless sky is its own prison. To look up at it is to see just how far away from God one can be. It's not quite hell, a place in which God has a unique, almost competitive interest. It's just a place he would never think to look-- a place he ignores, a place where, left to our own devices, we become exactly who we are.

act_title: Act Three: The Devil You Know
speaker: ira glass
utterance: That was Gary Shteyngart reading an original short story that he wrote for us. The other reader, the one at the end, was actor Josh Gad. Shteyngart is the author of a bunch of sad and funny novels. His latest is called Lake Success. And just so there's no confusion about what actually happened, yes, in real life, reportedly Sergey stabbed and nearly killed Oleg with a kitchen knife because Oleg was spoiling the endings to books that Sergey was reading.

ep-667.utterance: When Dave was turning his life around and trying different things and figuring out what to do next, one of the places he looked was to the Howard Stern Show. And I think that was a really good choice.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: I know everybody is not a fan of Howard Stern, but I am. And I think that one of the best things about the show is that it's always been a place where people talk with this kind of brutal and funny honesty about themselves. One of Howard's innovations is that he took the strain of crude, dark, confessional comedy that's always been a big part of stand-up, ever since Lenny Bruce-- Howard figured out a way to turn that into radio, daily radio.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: Anyway, to get back to this guy Dave, he loved that about the show. And in 2015, he was a few months sober, in his early 40s, working as a waiter at Katz's Deli in New York City. ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: Now sober in recovery, he needed a project. And he decided to a podcast about drugs with the feeling of the Howard Stern Show. Like, he remembered the years when comedian Artie Lange was on Howard Stern-- definitely my favorite period of Howard Stern.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: When Artie would come on every day. He would talk about his own drug problems. He would tell crazy stories. ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: They would spend hours in rehab smoking cigarettes and talking about the crazy things that they'd done on drugs. That's what they wanted the podcast to be. ep-667.utterance: This show is not necessarily about recovery.

ep-667.speaker: chris
ep-667.utterance: Mm-hmm.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: It's about drugs.

ep-667.speaker: chris
ep-667.utterance: Maybe eventually it will be who knows.

ep-667.utterance: If this show is ever about recovery, you got to get somebody else in this spot. I'm out.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: This show is about drug stories. It's not about recovery. It's not about doing the next right thing. It's about the last wrong thing.

ep-667.speaker: chris
ep-667.utterance: But maybe with the evolution of your recovery, that's what the show will become.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: And at this point, he'd been sober for nearly two years versus four months for Dave. And all of that gave him a different feeling about recovery and sobriety. ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: If this show was about recovery, it's going to be lame.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: So they'd tell drug stories. It wasn't meant to be good for you. It was meant to be fun. They listed it in the comedy section of iTunes, not self-help. If you want self-help, Dave had said, go to a meeting.

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: They were going to call the show War Stories, but there was already a podcast called War Stories. ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: And I think that's why we got along, 'cause we felt safe doing that with each other. You know, sometimes you feel a little judged with people when you recount funny stuff that's happened to you.

ep-667.speaker: chris

ep-667.utterance: By Episode 143, Dopey would sound completely different. ep-667.speaker: ira glass

ep-667.speaker: ira glass
ep-667.utterance: And really, both stories are dispatches from two very different battlefields. ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Dopey is not the kind of show you bring home to meet your parents. Dave and Chris swear a lot, for one thing. And obviously they're talking about heavy drug use. But it's not just that-- they can be insensitive and insulting too.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: It is not politically correct by design. ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: On the first few episodes of Dopey, they run through most of their favorite drug stories-- how Chris made wine from orange juice at rehab, how Dave once stayed up all night doing coke, heroin, and ecstasy before appearing on Howard Stern. ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis

They call their newfound audience The Dopey Nation.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Other people start emailing, leaving reviews on iTunes. Some listeners leave voicemails with their own war stories. Their downloads grow. By October, they average about 1,000 downloads an episode.

ep-667.utterance: Dave and Chris try to write back to every email they get. They respond to comments on Facebook and Twitter. People aren't turned off by the recovery talk. ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: When Dave and Chris talk about recovery, they often talk about abstinence and 12 step programs. ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: For a while on Dopey, Dave was pretty clear that he thought medications were dangerous, that you should learn to live without any substances. Chris was more middle of the road. Dave's opinions have changed by now. He feels like whatever works best for you is what you should do.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Less than a year into making Dopey, Dave moved out of the apartment with the fish tank and in with his partner Linda and their six-year-old daughter. Chris eventually moved to Boston and started working towards a doctoral degree in psychology.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: He was dating a med student named Annie. They lived together, had a dog. He was also working part-time for his sister's company-- which helps people who are struggling with addiction and other issues find treatment-- and he was working every other weekend at a sober living house.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: By episode 96 of Dopey, they're getting about 3,000 listeners a show. They decide to relabel the show. ep-667.utterance: He was staying up all night and sleeping during the day. She got suspicious he was using again, so she and Chris's sister arranged for a surprise drug test. On Monday, a guy showed up at their apartment and did a saliva test.

ep-667.utterance: That night, Annie told him she was going to stay with her parents. Chris left before her mom arrived to pick her up. Now she realized it was because he couldn't wait any longer to get high. Annie slept at her parents' house and went to work the next morning. But soon after, she went home to check on Chris.

ep-667.speaker: annie
ep-667.utterance: And I don't know if you want me to elaborate on how it was walking into the apartment.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: Yeah, you might as well.

ep-667.speaker: annie
ep-667.utterance: Or would you rather I not.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: No, you might as well.

ep-667.speaker: annie
ep-667.utterance: I walked in. The first thing I see is his shoes, so I figure, OK, he's here. And the vape is there, the keys are there, so I look at the couch. He's not on the couch. And I look at the bed, and he's not there.

ep-667.speaker: annie
ep-667.utterance: And then I [INAUDIBLE] bathroom, I go into the bathroom. He's not there. And that's when I start panicking, and-- and as I walk into the bedroom, on the side of the bed, I found him dead.

ep-667.speaker: annie
ep-667.utterance: I knew right away he was dead. Everything after that is somewhat foggy. I knew we had Narcan at home, because he always kept Narcan everywhere.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Narcan is a medication that can reverse an opioid overdose. You spray it up a person's nose.

ep-667.speaker: annie
ep-667.utterance: And I got the Narcan, but I knew it was too late. I just had to do it, because it was like the only thing I could do it at the moment.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Chris had cocaine, Xanax, alcohol, and fentanyl in his system. He was 33 years old. Soon after, a package arrived for him at their apartment. It was filled with drugs-- Percocet, cocaine, crack cocaine, heroin.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Annie scoured the apartment and Chris's car. She found a bunch of drug paraphernalia-- needles, some of which were used, and clean pee he'd ordered online. Also, she found a small medicated patch that wasn't in any packaging.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: She sent a picture of it to Dave. They couldn't be sure, but Dave thought it was probably fentanyl. Annie has a theory about Chris's relapse.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: He had recently injured himself doing a high karate kick to try to impress her. Something in his leg popped, he was in terrible pain.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: The doctor he saw wasn't his regular doctor and she thinks Chris got painkillers, fooled himself into thinking he could just take them for the pain and stop there. If Annie's theory is right, then Chris started using again two weeks after Todd's death and was dead three weeks later.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: I mean, when the news came, I got angry about it. And then the next morning I woke up and-- you know, I felt the day between the last time I had spoken to him. You know what I mean?

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: I felt the distance, and I was like, it just felt like it was becoming real. And then this morning I woke up, and I could hear his voice in my head like we were doing the show. I could hear his voice.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: And then I kind of woke up and it was another day since I had spoken to him. And it just-- it's like liquid becoming solid. You know what I mean? And it's like, you move away from this liquid feeling to this cold solid truth that he is never going to come back and it's over.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Dave hangs up with Annie. And now he's got to end this episode of Dopey without Chris for the first time.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: We'll just end it the way we always end it. And we'll say, stay strong Dopey Nation. And I said I would never say this, but Chris is dead, so I'll say toodles for Chris. And we love you. And everybody out there, please try to take care of yourself. All right.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Dave still makes Dopey-- by himself now. He's pulling in bigger guests like the comedian Marc Maron and the rapper Killer Mike. He gets about 6,000 downloads an episode now, but it's not the same show.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Dopey, as the nation knew it, is gone along with Chris. It's not a buddy comedy anymore. It's more of a straight interview show. There are fewer war stories, and when there are, the tone is different. Dave is different.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: There's this one moment in Episode 142, the last episode Dave and Chris did together, that I keep thinking about. Chris had just played a voicemail from a listener named Mike, who tells a story about hiding his pee in the closet of his bedroom. It's not important why. And afterwards, they get into a conversation about whether it's OK to laugh at drug stories.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: In the first episodes of Dopey, Dave was a solid yes on that-- that was the whole point of the show-- but now they've flipped sides. Chris says yes, it's fine to laugh. And Dave says this--

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: I think it's funny, but the fucked up thing-- and it might be the end of Dopey, right? Check this out. Like, I just feel like this guy-- he's like everyone's laughing about everything they're doing. And then they can just drop dead.

ep-667.speaker: chris
ep-667.utterance: But what's the flipside? Morbid reality the whole time until you die?

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: No, dude. I think it's funny. I think the urine is funny. I think that shit is hysterical. But it's like laughing on the train tracks and not seeing the fucking train coming. I don't think morbid reality is better. No, of course not. I'm just saying it's sad, you know?

ep-667.speaker: chris
ep-667.utterance: We laugh on the train tracks, but we have the right to laugh on the train tracks. It'd be much different if someone had never struggled. And the truth is that when we were struggling, the person who would tell a story that was terrifying and laugh at it, might have a better chance at reaching us and getting us to stop than the person who's morbid reality.

ep-667.speaker: dave
ep-667.utterance: I just feel responsible. I think it's obviously because of Todd's death that when we laugh at stuff, I just want to throw it out there that at any second, Mike could be dead. Because Mike's still using. And there's fentanyl everywhere. And it's killing everybody. That's what I'm saying. How's that?

ep-667.speaker: chris
ep-667.utterance: Yes, no, of course. Yeah.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: Dave told me, he always thought Dopey was good for him and Chris, for their sobriety. He thought their creation would protect them, but it didn't. Chris is gone. Dopey, it turns out, was its own war story, playing out week by week.

ep-667.speaker: dana chivvis
ep-667.utterance: So now on the show, Dave's mission has changed. The drug stories aren't just in service of a laugh now, they're in service of an urgent message. You could die. Todd died. Chris died. You could die.
